meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith, Notre Dame
meeting_annotations.transcript: So I think the way we're going to do this is we're going to go around and have each of the PIs talk a little bit about what they're doing and what they're thinking about and then we'll just open it up for discussion. So I'm happy to start. I'm Brad Smith at Notre Dame. We're interested in the general area of how cells make decisions and how they do that in a robust way.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith, Notre Dame
meeting_annotations.transcript: And so we're thinking about that in the context of a couple of different projects. One is how cells decide whether to move or not. So we're looking at cell migration and how cells integrate signals to decide whether to move. And then the other thing we're looking at is how cells decide whether to differentiate or not. And so we're looking at stem cell differentiation and how cells integrate signals to decide whether to differentiate. And so we're using a combination of experiments and modeling to try to understand how cells make these decisions in a robust way.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia (Genia) Kozorovitsky (she/her), Northwestern U
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Genia Kozorovitsky from Northwestern. I'm really excited to be here. I'm a neurobiologist and my lab studies how the brain changes in response to social experiences. So we're really interested in how social signals are encoded in the brain and how they change the brain.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith, Notre Dame
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great, thanks Genia. So we'll just keep going around. So we'll go to Barbara next. Barbara, do you want to tell us a little bit about what you're doing?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Yevgenia (Genia) Kozorovitsky (she/her), Northwestern U
meeting_annotations.transcript: No worries. So we're really interested in how social isolation changes the brain and we're looking at that from a number of different angles. So we're looking at how social isolation changes the structure of neurons, how it changes the activity of neurons, and how it changes the expression of genes in neurons. And we're using a combination of techniques to do that including electrophysiology, imaging, and molecular biology.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Brad Smith, Notre Dame
meeting_annotations.transcript: Great, thanks Genia. Okay, Barbara, do you want to tell us a little bit about what you're doing?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You | MIT
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi everyone, I'm Sixian from MIT. So my lab is generally interested in how cells sense and respond to mechanical cues in their environment. meeting_annotations.speaker: Sixian You | MIT

meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, I'm Luke Mortensen. I'm at the University of Georgia.
